assetIdentification.assetDescription: System that interprets voice commands from vehicle occupants to control various vehicle functions including navigation, phone calls, media playback, climate control, and vehicle settings

confidentiality.description: The system shall protect the confidentiality of voice recordings, voice signatures, user profiles, and command history
confidentiality.justification: Voice data is classified as biometric data under privacy regulations and may contain sensitive personal information

integrity.description: The system shall ensure the integrity of voice commands and prevent unauthorized modification of system behavior
integrity.justification: Tampering with voice recognition could lead to execution of unintended commands or bypassing of authentication

availability.description: The system shall maintain availability of voice command functions under adverse conditions
availability.justification: Users may rely on voice commands for hands-free operation of vehicle functions, particularly while driving

authentication.description: The system shall verify the authenticity of users for sensitive commands and personalized functions
authentication.justification: Voice authentication is used to control access to personal profiles and restricted functions

authorization.description: The system shall authorize voice commands based on user permissions and vehicle state
authorization.justification: Different users may have different levels of access to vehicle functions via voice commands

threatScenarios.title: Voice Command Spoofing
threatScenarios.threatDescription: An attacker uses synthetic speech or replayed recordings to issue unauthorized voice commands that are accepted as legitimate by the Voice Recognition System

attackVector.description: Attack can be conducted through direct access to vehicle microphones or via compromised connected devices (e.g., smartphones, Bluetooth connections)

attackSteps: Attacker records or synthesizes voice commands that mimic an authorized user
Attacker plays back these commands within microphone range or injects them digitally through a compromised connected interface
Voice Recognition System processes and executes the commands without detecting the spoofing

unsafeControlActions: Voice system accepts and executes commands without proper verification of speaker authenticity
Voice system executes safety-sensitive commands without additional confirmation
controlFlaws: Insufficient contextual analysis of command patterns
Lack of liveness detection for voice inputs
causalFactors: Advanced voice synthesis technology becoming more accessible
Difficulty distinguishing between recorded and live voice
Limited computational resources for advanced voice authentication

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: While voice spoofing technology is becoming more accessible, effective attacks still require moderate sophistication and proximity to the vehicle

likelihoods.justification: Voice spoofing technologies are becoming increasingly sophisticated, but effective attacks against modern voice recognition systems still require technical expertise

vulnerabilities.description: Lack of multi-factor authentication for critical voice commands
Limited contextual analysis for suspicious command patterns

existingControls.description: Basic voice pattern recognition for registered users
existingControls.justification: Current pattern matching is vulnerable to sophisticated voice synthesis attacks
Provides some protection but could be bypassed in a continuous attack sequence

threatScenarios.title: Voice Authentication Bypass
threatScenarios.threatDescription: An attacker exploits weaknesses in the voice-based authentication system to gain unauthorized access to restricted functions, personal profiles, or payment capabilities

attackVector.description: Attack requires either physical proximity to the vehicle or compromised connected devices with access to the voice authentication system

attackSteps: Attacker identifies vulnerabilities in the voice authentication implementation
Attacker bypasses authentication through techniques such as voice synthesis, replay attacks, or exploitation of implementation flaws
Attacker gains access to restricted functions, personal profiles, or payment capabilities

unsafeControlActions: Voice authentication system grants access without proper verification
Voice authentication system fails to detect synthetic or replayed voice samples
Authentication system does not implement adequate timeout or lockout mechanisms
controlFlaws: Insufficient countermeasures against known bypass techniques
Lack of additional authentication factors for high-value functions
causalFactors: Variations in ambient noise conditions affecting authentication reliability

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: Bypassing voice authentication requires specialized knowledge and tools, but is achievable by a motivated attacker with moderate resources

likelihoods.justification: Voice biometric systems have known vulnerabilities, though exploiting them requires technical expertise and specific knowledge of the target system

vulnerabilities.description: Lack of anti-replay protections for voice samples
Absence of multi-factor authentication for high-value functions

existingControls.description: Voice biometric verification for user profiles
existingControls.justification: Provides baseline protection but may be vulnerable to sophisticated attacks

existingControls.description: PIN code fallback for payment authorization
existingControls.justification: Additional factor improves security but implementation may have weaknesses

threatScenarios.title: Voice Data Exfiltration
threatScenarios.threatDescription: An attacker gains unauthorized access to stored voice recordings, command history, or voice signatures, leading to privacy violations and potential misuse of biometric data

attackVector.description: Attack requires access to the infotainment system's internal storage, databases, or communication channels where voice data is processed or transmitted

attackSteps: Attacker gains access to the voice data storage through exploitation of system vulnerabilities
Attacker extracts voice recordings, command history, or voice signature data
Attacker exfiltrates data for later analysis or misuse (identity theft, privacy violations)

unsafeControlActions: System stores voice data without adequate encryption
System fails to implement proper access controls for voice databases
System retains voice data longer than necessary for its function
controlFlaws: Inadequate encryption of sensitive voice data
Insufficient access controls for voice databases
Lack of data minimization principles in implementation
causalFactors: Need to process voice data for command recognition and personalization
Storage of voice samples for system training and improvement
Decentralized processing across multiple system components

attackFeasibilityRating.justification: Data exfiltration requires system access and knowledge of storage mechanisms, representing a moderate level of difficulty

likelihoods.justification: Voice data may be stored across various system components with different security levels, creating potential weaknesses an attacker could exploit

vulnerabilities.description: Unencrypted or weakly encrypted voice data storage
Inadequate access controls for voice databases

existingControls.description: Basic encryption of voice data at rest
existingControls.justification: Provides some protection but implementation may have weaknesses

existingControls.description: User controls for voice data deletion
existingControls.justification: Allows users to request deletion but doesn't prevent initial collection or unauthorized access

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall provide voice-based control of vehicle functions
The system shall support voice-based user authentication
The system shall process and store voice data for command recognition
The system shall comply with all applicable privacy regulations

keyTerms.Threat Scenario: Description of how a threat agent could exploit vulnerabilities to cause damage
keyTerms.Attack Vector: Path or means by which an attacker can gain access to a system to deliver a malicious outcome
keyTerms.Attack Feasibility: Measure of how difficult it would be for an attacker to successfully exploit a vulnerability
keyTerms.STPA: Systems-Theoretic Process Analysis - a hazard analysis technique
keyTerms.CVSS: Common Vulnerability Scoring System - a framework for rating the severity of security vulnerabilities
keyTerms.CWE: Common Weakness Enumeration - a list of software and hardware weakness types
keyTerms.CVE: Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures - a list of publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities
keyTerms.Voice Spoofing: Using synthetic or recorded voice to mimic an authorized user
keyTerms.Voice Authentication: Using voice biometrics to verify a user's identity

contentSummary: This TARA Threat Scenarios document identifies and analyzes three primary threats to the Voice Recognition System: Voice Command Spoofing (TS-VR-01), where an attacker uses synthetic speech or replayed recordings to issue unauthorized commands; Voice Authentication Bypass (TS-VR-02), where an attacker circumvents voice-based authentication to gain unauthorized access to restricted functions; and Voice Data Exfiltration (TS-VR-03), where voice recordings and biometric data are accessed without authorization. Each threat scenario includes a detailed attack vector analysis, step-by-step attack progression, STPA analysis of control flaws, and attack feasibility assessment using the CVSS Base method. Multiple vulnerabilities are identified for each scenario, including insufficient multi-factor authentication, weak liveness detection, inadequate encryption, and excessive data retention. The document also evaluates existing controls, noting their limitations in addressing these threats. This analysis provides the foundation for subsequent risk assessment and security requirements development for the Voice Recognition System.
